literals: 'webdev-setup-tools'
'engines'
'java'
'This prompt will walk you through\nthe installation and setup of the official oracle java jdk.'
'\nWhen a step has been completed, press enter to continue to the next step.\nPlease press enter to begin.'
'go to the url http://www.oracle.com/technetwork/java/javase/downloads'
'click on the jdk download link to be redirected to the download page for all systems.'
'accept the license agreement, then download the version matching your operating system.'
'\nFor most Apple OSX configurations, this auto configures your path, so you can ignore the subsequent steps.'
'win32'
'accept the default path and tools for your new java installation.'
'after the download, you will need to first unzip this folder,\nthen add this location to your system path.'
'win32'
'type "environment variables" into your start button menu or search bar and click enter.'
'press ctrl + alt + t to launch a terminal'
'win32'
'click on the "environment variables" button near the bottom.'
'type nano (or your text editor of choice) ~/.bash_profile (.bashrc, .bash_profile, .zshrc, etc.) and press enter'
'win32'
'in the lower window marked "system variables" you should see a variable marked "Path".\nClick on this value to modify it.'

'Scroll to the end of the file. If java has not been added to your environment, you can add it with the followind:
JAVA_HOME=/usr/lib/jvm/{your java version here}
export JAVA_HOME
Save the file and exit. '
'reload the system path by pressing . /etc/environment or close the terminal.'
'win32'
'click on the button labeled "New", or double click on "Path"'
'win32'
'paste the path to your java sdk in this box. typically, this path is of '
'the form\nC:\\Program Files\\Java\\jdk1.8.0_141\\bin, but this is unique to each installation.'
'win32'
'Next, you will need to add a System Variable for "JAVA_HOME".\nClick new under the box for system variables.\nA box should pop up with values '
'for the variable name and the value. Enter "JAVA_HOME" as the name.\nFor the value, Enter "C:\\Program Files\\Java\\jdk1.8.0_141", but this is unique to each installation.'
'open a new terminal then type "javac -v".\nIf this was done correctly, you should see output like "javac 1.8.0_141".'
'This concludes the java jdk setup.'
'checking java version compatibility.'
'javac -version'
'no jdk version found on this computer'
'java version '
' is up to date'
'no compatible jdk version found on this computer'
comments: by default the output is directed to stderr
important to test the java compiler
java commands are redirected to stderr in both windows and linux environments
